evaluationChecklist.summary:
Definitions

1. Malhar

Malhar is an open source codec and operator library.

2. Apex

The interface between the hadoop clusters and the intructions for the hadoop clusters.

3. Hadoop Clusters

Collection of Nodes that have been assigned work to perform.

4. Java programming language

Language used to write programs that can use the Malhar library. Source code can then be changed into .apa programs so that they can be run by Apex.

5. Apache Maven

Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool.

 

Apache apex requires previous knowledge about data streaming services to fully leverage. It also has a high barrier to entry. In light of this, high scores were given for a number of factors where the developers went to exceptional lengths to lower the barrier to entry and make the asset easier to use.

Some of these items are listed here:

1. A VM is provided(from data torrent) with Apex and Hadoop services pre-installed.

2. A Docker image is provided with Apex and Hadoop services pre-installed.

3. It is possible to create "Apex Applications" that simulate similiar behavior as if they were run on clusters. These "Apex Applications" can be run without installing Apex.

4. There is a large amount of documentation detailing test cases, test data, use cases, and example problems. 

Lower scores were awarded to Apache Apex principally due to the lack of documentation detailing things such as performance, I/O testing, and Error handling.

 

Here is included a discussion on the testing that was done for this evaluation.

For the tests that were performed the tester followed an online tutorial to create two apex programs.

The first one would basically take in a number of input files, count the words in the files and output the word frequency of all the input files. The tester was not able to complete this test due to errors encountered when "launching" the apex program.  To be clear this asset is used by many companies and can integrate with many other products and apache services, see here. This summary is simply stating that the tester was unable to complete testing due to errors encountered while following the online tutorial step.

For the second test, the tester followed online instructions to compute pi using a monte carlo scheme. The results of this test are shown in the testing section. 

Final summary review after completing testing.

Apex is a powerful and easy to implement stream processor made by Datatorrent and configured to run on hadoop services. Along with the concept of operators,(ways to pipe data to and from nodes for processing) it also has access to the Malhar library.(A large collection of prebuilt operators) Thus enabling users to get up and running quickly without the need to worry about how to receive, process and send data to other nodes in the graph. 

One convenient way to think of how apex works is by visualizing a Directed Acyclic Graph. Where the edges are the data streams and the nodes are the "operators" that are receiving, processing and sending the data to another stream. In a sense each operator has an "input" port and an "output" port. The data streams are merely starting at a node, getting processed, and then get piped into other nodes. Now that we have the idea of the nodes and the edges, or more specifically the operators and the data streams we can now "distribute" the "nodes" across the cluster and simply pipe the data to and from these individual nodes on the cluster. 

In dealing with faults and outages there is a runtime component that running alongside the application, and when a "node" or operator goes down it is restored to a valid state or an earlier "checkpoint" where state is preserved. With regards to scalability the "nodes" can be broken down and partitioned into multiple instances to allow for handling larger amounts of data. Finally the operational insight tool shows how each data point is performing and can record data.

 

The following video is reccomended for greater understanding of Apex and its functions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z6RdpT50G_o

question.narrative:
First of all, this question deals with who the main customer is for DI2E Framework assets.  The main customer is a developer who is designing and building a solution to a particular problem, and wants to know whether there are any re-usable assets that exist that they can leverage in their solution.  If an asset does exist, but the developers who need to re-use the asset cannot find the asset, the asset is not really re-usable in the grand scheme of things. 

The idea here is to think about how a developer would look for an asset if they didn't know the asset existed.  They won't necessarily know the name of the asset or the asset owner - instead they will search on terms associated with the functionality they are interested in by typing those terms into Google and/or an Intelink search and reviewing the first few pages of results.  What we are looking for is "hits" on the asset within the first few pages of results.  If the search results do return hits on the asset but the hits are buried somewhere after page 3 of results, then the developer will likely not find them.  Also, the hits should link to a good description of the asset.  

This is all enabled by having a full description of the asset (full = functionality of the asset is described in various layman's and expert terms) in a place that Internet and/or major DoD/IC search engines can crawl and index (e.g., on a public web page or, if the asset is FOUO on Intelink).  If, for example, a web page that describes the asset is kept behind a firewall such that no search engine crawlers can access it, the developer searching for the asset using well-known search tools will not be able to find it.

This is just as applicable for COTS products as it is for FOSS or GOSS.

question.objective:
Developers generally use a search engine or a well-known registry (e.g., http://www.programmableweb.com ) to find things. Keying terms associated with the asset's functionality into a search engine should get "hits" on the asset within the first few pages of results. How do developers look for an asset if they don't know the asset's name or even if it exists?

Search engines index web pages. To help developers find your asset, a public web page containing the following should be made available:

  1. Which versions of the asset are currently available 
  2. A narrative of the asset's functionality (i.e., what the asset "does") 
  3. Any APIs and supported protocols associated with the asset

It is important to provide up-to-date information so that the actual data indexed by search engines is current. Make sure the public web pages have enough information to assist the potential consumer to make an informed decision about whether or not the asset can meet their needs.

This question is concerned not so much with the description of the asset, but with the asset itself and whether a developer can actually get access to the asset.  The customer for the asset in this case is the developer who wants to re-use the asset, so the developer is interested in where they can either download the asset binaries and/or buildable source code.  These places need to be stable and accessible.  So, for example if the asset binaries and source code is kept in a repository behind a firewall that nobody outside that firewall can get to, it is not accessible.  If the URLs to the asset download page keeps changing, it is not in a stable location. 

For GOTS and GOSS assets, both the binaries and the source code "belong" to the government, and therefore both should be accessible to developers of government programs.  In today's world, accessible means that you can download via the Internet, and/or via NIPR, SIPR, or JWICS depending on the classification of the asset.  In the case of COTS, it is expected that only the binaries will be made available and accessible, and that accessible in this case means that a developer can download the binaries via the Internet.  They may need a license key to "unlock" the binaries, but otherwise the binaries are accessible.    

NOTE: For both GOSS and FOSS, by definition, both the source and binaries should be made available.  If only the binaries are made available or if only the source is made available and you have to build the source to get a binary, the "score" should be lowered by at least one over what you would give if both the binaries and source are available.

This question applies to re-deployable assets, and is intended to expose any burdens or obstacles that are in the way of a developer being able to download source code for an asset to re-use. It is also intended to see if source code is even allowed to be acquired and used for the asset.

Examples of burdens that exist that need to be exposed include the following:

  1. Developer needs a CAC card.  Although DoD and IC PKI (e.g., CAC cards, SIPR tokens, etc.) provide  analysts and "end users" accessibility to DoD and IC operational systems, it actually hinders those (such as developers) who cannot get those DoD and IC PKI credentials.  Therefore, requiring a CAC card (or similar DoD/IC PKI credential) to access binaries and source code is tantamount to severely limiting the user base that can access that asset.

Developer needs a special account - AND - the account provisioning process is not set up for external members to request or get accounts.  In other words, if someone wants to access the binaries or source code for an asset and needs an account to do so, but is unable to get that account because there are no instructions provided (or for other reasons can't get an account), then the asset is not re-usable.

question.narrative:
When an asset is made available for re-use, sometimes it requires other "things" to be in place in order for it to function.  For example, if a redeployable capability (e.g., a WebApp) is packaged for re-use as a .war file, then it requires a JEE container (aka app server) in order to execute.  With today's programming techniques and patterns, this is to be expected.  However, sometimes when such an application is created, it leverages functions from the container that are proprietary to the particular container product.  For example, a WebApp might leverage functions that are proprietary to, say, a WebLogic app server.  In this case, you cannot reuse the component unless you also purchase and install, specifically, a WebLogic container.  That still may not be all, though, as you may have to install a specific version of the WebLogic container. 

Additional examples of dependencies include the following:

  • A back-end database.  In this case, the dependency may be on any JDBC or ODBC conformant relational database, or on a specific database product - such as SQL server or Oracle, or Mongo or Accumulo, etc.  
  • A back-end server component.  For example, a map widget might be dependent upon Ozone Widget Framework as well as an OGC Web Map Service.
  • A specific operating system (e.g., Linux, Windows, etc.) 
  • A specific hardware configuration (e.g., x86, Solaris, etc.)
  • An entire system (i.e., the asset cannot be extracted from the larger system it is part of)

The number and type of dependencies required to re-use a component is an important consideration in whether a component can be easily re-used or not.  For example, if an asset requires the purchase of Oracle middleware (app server and database) in order to run, and that program has no extra money for additional software licenses but they have already purchased Oracle middleware for other reasons, than that dependency is reasonable for that particular program.  However, if the program has not already purchased the Oracle middleware licenses, then the dependency on such middleware components can preclude that program from re-using that particular asset. 

In general, the less dependencies, and the more generic any given dependency, the better.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

question.narrative:
This question looks to see whether an asset is "usable" in the general sense, that is, the functionality and features of the asset as contained in the asset's publicly discoverable capability descriptions are fully implemented and available in the current release package. The intention is not to conduct a formal IV&V on whether the asset satisfies all of its functional requirements, but rather a high level check to make sure an ordinary user will not be surprised to find promised functionality missing. Unavailable and planned features should clearly marked as such in both the UI and documentation.

In addition to checking the asset's discovery metadata and its documentation package, to fully answer the question usually requires downloading and installing the asset (in the case of a widget,a  web service, or other redeployable component) or accessing its endpoint (in the case of an enterprise service), and exercising some use case scenarios (i.e., "happy path" test cases). If it is not feasible to do so, an alternative would be to interview current users or evaluate any existing test documentation to ensure that functionality was tested.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.  Although it is expected that COTS will score highly on this question, it is not guaranteed to be so as many COTS products market themselves as more feature complete than they actually are.

Example best answer: All promised features are fully implemented and functional in current implementation.

Example good answer: Some minor features as described in discovery metadata missing or under development; they are clearly marked as such in both UI and documentation.

Example bad answer: Major features as described in discovery metadata are missing or not fully implemented in current implementation, not yet "ready for prime time".

question.narrative:
The intent of this question is on the intuitiveness of the design, i.e. can a user use the system without seeking external help (e.g. training or documentation)? Note that the intuitiveness may also depend on the efficiency level of the user: an expert user, for example, may want shortcuts or customized sequences tailored to his/her tasks, which may not be as intuitive to a novice user. The UI platform also play an important role: Intuitive controls in a desktop-based web browser (e.g. right-clicks or control-key sequences), for instance, may not be suitable for mobile devices.

The definition of a UI design's "goodness" may be difficult to come by, but oftentimes "you know it when you see it". In other words, although the criteria of a good UI design is somewhat subjective, there are well-established (albeit sometimes tacit) guidelines and best practices that people follow.

A good user interface (UI) design is important in boosting a user's productivity and efficiency in completing tasks and ensuring operational success. For a newly developed component or system, it is also critical in gaining user acceptance. ISO 9241-11 suggests that measures of usability should cover

  • effectiveness ( the ability of users to complete tasks using the system, and the quality of the output of those tasks),
  • efficiency ( the level of resource consumed in performing tasks)
  • satisfaction (usersâ€™ subjective reactions to using the system).

To score high in this question, the UI component should ideally possess the following characteristics:

  • Intuitive controls suitable for the specific UI platform (e.g. desktop thick clients, browser-based thin clients, mobile/handheld devices, embedded instrument panels, etc.)
  • Easy-to-follow navigation controls and error preventions tailored to the usage context (e.g. bread crumbs, greying out non-applicable inputs, etc.)
  • Tailored controls based on user proficiency levels and/or operator communities
  • Positive feedback from real user experience

A lack thereof would result in a low score.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.  Although one would expect COTS products to score highly for this question, it is not guaranteed to be so.  Some COTS products can have very complex and difficult to understand UIs.

Example best answer: Intuitive UI controls exist for user navigation, error prevention etc., for the target platform (e.g., desktop, mobile devices, servers); a casual / novice user can use the system without prior training or documentation

Example good answer: Limited UI controls (such as navigation and error prevention) exist for guiding a user, but may require training and documentation for using advanced features of the component

Example bad answer: UI design not intuitive; a casual user cannot use the system without prior training
question.objective:
Ascertain the intuitiveness of the design. Can a user use the system without seeking external help (e.g. training or documentation)? This is generally enabled by following well-known patterns, conventions (e.g. command shortcuts, undo/redo) and standards that the typical end user is already familiar with, and which take advantage of human factors studies to help ensure easy to use and intuitive design.

Some UIs are intentionally targeted for the expert user, who may want shortcuts or customized sequences tailored to expert tasks, and as a result may not be as intuitive to a novice user.

question.narrative:
Question: Do errors get conveyed to the consumer (end user or consuming application) in a meaningful manner?

 

Narrative: Error messages should be presented to consumers (whether end user in the case of widgets, or consuming applications in the case of enterprise services or APIs from redeployable capabilities) in a way that is informative, easy to understand, and (when possible) actionable by providing helpful information on alternatives/mitigations/resolutions (i.e., is an error message that gives reasonable information they could be conveyed to a sys admin or help desk). This question is not specific to user-facing components such as web pages and widgets. Even machine-to-machine services and backend components should try to provide meaningful error messages that can eventually help the end user understand the reason of the error.

In general, "raw" error messages (e.g. Java stack traces, HTTP error codes, Apache Tomcat out-of-the-box error page, etc.) should never just be passed directly on to the consumer.  Instead, they should be "wrapped" when logged (see question Q390) and an actionable and informative human-understandable message relayed either directly to the end user in the case of widgets, or to a consuming application in the case of an enterprise service.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.  For COTS or GOTS where source code is not provided, answering this question will require looking a documentation of error codes and logging, as well as invoking the error handling and reading the logs and returned error codes.

Example best answer:  Meaningful error messages are conveyed with helpful information on error resolution (e.g. wait for certain time period; contact system admin or helpdesk).

Example good answer: Meaningful error messages are conveyed but no helpful information is available for error resolution.

Example bad answer: "Raw" error messages (e.g. stack traces) are conveyed with no meaningful explanation, or error messages return no information (e.g., "an error has occured"), are extremely generic (e.g., "Connection failed"), or occur silently.

Note to the evaluator: the answer to this question is best determined via a combination of code inspection, documentation, and actual performance testing that explicitly exercises the error handling.  However, it is recognized that the evaluator may not have the resources to perform the testing that is required, in which case relying on test plans and results documentation from the component provider (assuming the test plans and results explicitly include error handling) and/or, in cases where source code is available, spot checking said code, is sufficient.  Spot checking code involves searching the code for error messages and looking at a sample set of error messages. 

 

Question: Can the root cause of errors be easily determined?

 

Narrative: This question is about whether assets can generate and communicate internal state information when an error occurs so that the root cause of the error can be determined by an authorized person (e.g., system administrator).  In a component-based architecture, a user request is usually fulfilled by a set of interacting software components that may be individually developed and configured. This makes determining the root cause of an error more challenging compared with a tightly-coupled, "stove-piped" system. When evaluating a component-based software asset as a reuse candidate, a number of factors come into play with regard to its error handling ability:

  • Basic enablers to error diagnosis, i.e., the component's internal error logging and error escalation mechanisms. A well-designed component usually has the ability to wrap and propagate errors meaningfully while maintaining the error traces. For example, an EJB component may replace an SQL exception from a database query with a more meaningful error message to the UI layer. The original error is still logged and maintained for diagnosis purposes. 
  • The component's ability to support integrated component-level monitoring. A component may have multiple log files and correlating an error across files to determine the actual case can be very difficult. A well designed component will provide meaningful, correlated messages to aid in debugging. For example, debugging SSL errors can be very complicated due to many error messages spread across multiple error logs. 
  • The component's ability to integrate with external monitoring software via APIs, supporting integrated software-level monitoring. Although a component may have its own administration console for health and status monitoring, an administrator for a large-scale system may be burdened with having to monitor multiple component-level consoles at runtime, which quickly becomes labor intensive. A better option would be to send component-level metrics to a designated monitoring software, which can ingest, aggregate and visualize data in a consistent manner. The Java Management eXtension (JMX) API, for example, allow JEE components output their management information to the container.
  • The component's ability to support integrated system-level monitoring. Software errors, esp. the critical ones, are often caused by underlying hardware failures (e.g. failure of a storage disk, a CPU, or a data communication line). For the overall system, software level error messages must be correlated with hardware-level monitoring to provide the end-to-end picture of system health. Pre-built integration plugins with system monitoring software (e.g. Nagios, HP OpenView, IBM Tuxedo), in particular can give a component the maximum ability for root cause analysis.

When evaluating an asset's documentation, the evaluator should look for design and testing documentation on its error propagation design, its support of standard monitoring/management APIs, and its integration with existing software-level and/or system-level monitoring software. In the case when detailed technical documentation is not available, code reviews may offer additional insight.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS - though for COTS and GOTS where source code is not provided this question should be answered based on available documentation and via evaluating logs after forcing some error conditions.

Example best answer:  Logging is well-coordinated across sub-components, both in common terminology and format, timestamps, etc., as well as in logging to a common file or coordinated files. Error messages in log files are meaningful and useful to log monitoring tools such as Splunk.  "System-level monitoring": Integration interfaces (e.g., SNMP, JMX) may be provided for integration with a system management tool (e.g. HP OpenView, Nagios).

Example good answer:  Logging is somewhat coordinated across sub-components, either in common terminology and format, timestamps, etc., or in logging to a common file. Most error messages in log files are meaningful ."Software-level monitoring": Cascading errors are logged (e.g. through stack traces) so that the originating software component or module can be determined

Example bad answer: Logging is not coordinated across sub-components (different sub-components log to different files and use differing message formats).  Only high level error messages are logged with no meaningful debugging information provided. Unable to determine root cause of errors

question.narrative:
This question focus on whether error handling is built into the asset.  When an error occurs and is not captured and handled, it may result in an asset freezing, crashing, or otherwise ceasing to function, and then operator intervention to resume service - for example by stopping and re-starting the asset. In the worst cases, a crashed asset leaves various subcomponents in an indeterminate state (e.g., asset crashes in the middle of a multi-step process) so that when the asset is re-started there is no way to tell what step it was in and what steps had completed. Error handling can "catch" errors when they are generated and handle them appropriately.  For example, if a serious error is generated by the operating system, the asset can catch that error and write its current state to a log file and close any open connections before shutting down.  Robust error handling enhances the predictability and resiliency of the component, thereby making it a more desirable reuse target.  Specifically, graceful error handling includes at least the following aspects:

  • Exceptions / alternative user actions should be properly identified and handled, so that they don't cause the software component to become unresponsive or worse, go into an illegal state. Such user actions may include out-of-range input values (e.g. divide by zero), large volume of input/output data (e.g. uploading a big file), illegal configurations (e.g., using an unsupported browser or browser version), etc.
  • Graceful degradation of performance when the component is under load/stress/failure. The load/stress/failure may be caused either by heavy user loads or underlying hardware/software failures such as a crash of an internal database or an outage of an application server instance under a clustered configuration.  Avoiding total system crash and allowing at least partial system functionality in this case requires careful planning and design in advance, and is usually harder to achieve than handling functional exceptions.

To score high in this question, the component provider would have ensured that exceptions are caught at all places where they can occur and are properly handled.  Additionally, such exception handling is exercised in testing (with resulting test cases and results provided for review).  Note that exception handling should also consider load conditions to ensure that the asset degraded gracefully under such load vice getting into indeterminate state or stopping altogether.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.  However, for those COTS or GOTS assets where source code is not provided, the only ways to validate this question are to look at documentation for error codes and logging, as well as to actually test the asset with invalid parameters in order to invoke the error handling code.

Example best answer: The asset gracefully handles errors and remains stable under most operating conditions.

Example good answer: The asset handles some errors and often remains stable.

Example bad answer: The asset requires frequent operator or user intervention to continue working.

question.narrative:
This question is getting at how well the service API is designed.  A good API is intuitive and follows good design principles - and in particular it is designed from the perspective of the developer who has to invoke the API (as opposed to the developer who just leverages some automated tools to expose existing functionality).  For SOAP calls, this includes the following: the naming convention and actual names of the methods, arguments, and the URLs to the endpoints, whether HTTP verbs are used appropriately, whether the naming of the methods and arguments is consistent with the functionality exposed

Another way to understand what we are looking for in this questions is how easy it is for a developer to be able to understand, and write code to invoke, the API of the service.  It is important to note here that there is some ambiguity as to what people generally mean by the term "service". Some folks equate "service" with a specific API call ("operation" or "method"), for example, an API that contains 4 calls would be considered as 4 "services".  On the other hand, some equate "service" with something more abstract that can be accessed by API calls, for example, a single service API might provide 4 calls to access the one service's functionality.  This question considers service in the latter case, and in general, from the perspective of a human developer who has to design and code a consuming application, the latter case is more meaningful, and the API to the service should be designed with this human developer in mind. 

Too often, APIs to services are designed and implemented only considering the effort required for the service developer, and not considering the effort required of the consuming developer.  For SOAP services, this often manifests in developers using a tool like Java2WSDL to auto-generate SOAP operations and arguments from existing Java classes. resulting in interfaces and WSDL description documents that are cryptic (i.e., hard for a developer to understand) and that map Java class methods directly to SOAP operations.   This can be somewhat mitigated if the Java class being exposed was specifically implemented as an interface class and designed to be easy to understand and invoke, but even in these cases the method arguments still tend to be cryptic.  If a service provider wants to leverage Java2WSDL, they can do so as a starting point, but then will need to manually adjust the resulting WSDL to be more "developer friendly" in terms of argument names and added comments.  In the case of RESTful web services, the focus on ease of implementation for the service developer manifests as poorly organized web resources and not using the HTTP verbs, error codes, caching MIME types and hypermedia correctly.

In order to score highly in this question, the API calls associated with a service:

  1. should be easily understood as to the specific parts of the service functionality they invoke along with any necessary ordering of those methods,
  2. should use current web protocols (e.g., JSON over HTTP) and use them correctly (e.g., appropriate HTTP verbs, error codes, caching, MIME types and hypermedia, i.e., passing links to other service endpoints in the response). 
  3. should come with provided examples of how to invoke the API calls, expected responses, and allowable error codes, along with the API definition. 
  4. should use plain english terms for method (operation) and argument names
  5. should be as generic as possible (e.g., method call should be more generic, with specificity captured in the document passed in (in the case of SOAP calls), or the URI path
  6. should not require any proprietary client side modules in order to access the service

Note that this question somewhat overlaps with question 200, but is more specifically focused on the ease of invocation.

Note that applying the RESTful paradigm in terms of organization of functionality and URL naming are a part of making the API calls more understandable.  This applies even when using SOAP, since SOAP service endpoints are identified by URLs.  There are numerous examples of how to organize web resources to be scalable and how to name them to be understandable (e.g., resources = nouns). 

The bottom line is that when a developer who is not familiar with the service can, just by looking at the API, understand how to invoke the service, and that the API itself leverages appropriate web protocols and paradigms, the service is much easier to invoke.

A good primer on how to design good APIs is included in "pragmatic RESTful principles" such as those defined in http://www.vinaysahni.com/best-practices-for-a-pragmatic-restful-api

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: API follows all 6 of the "shoulds" identified above

Example good answer: API follows at least 3 of the "shoulds" identified above

Example bad answer: API follows none of the "shoulds" identified above

question.narrative:
The APIs of an asset may change over time. Since these changes directly impact the consuming applications, they need to be managed carefully. Note that the API changes may or may not coincide with implementation changes of the asset. Ideally, these changes should follow separate lifecycles and be governed separately. Asset back-end APIs, such as SOAP or RESTful interfaces, should follow design patterns and best practices that facilitate implementation-independence, information hiding, and endpoint versioning. Such patterns and best practices should include, at the minimum:

  • Data formats are particularly important when designing for resilience to change. For many formats (e.g., XML) there are many design patterns that help to provide resilience (e.g., Russian Doll, Venetian Blind). 
  • Use of standards-based data transfer formats (such as SOAP, XML, JSON, KML, etc.), preferably over HTTP/S.
  • Information hiding such that API methods and arguments do not encompass implementation-specific data (e.g. table names and column headers from the underlying database).
  • Versioning of the API endpoints. For RESTful interfaces, the API should ideally include a versioning identifier as part of the overall URI/URL. For SOAP web services or other session-oriented protocols (e.g. CORBA/IIOP), the service interface should have discoverable metadata that include versioning attributes (e.g. in a service registry).

Moreover, the asset provider should see communicate the API changes to consumers proactively and manage their expectations.

Note that this also applies to web widgets.  In the case of web widgets, the APIs should be managed in a way that backwards compatibility is maintained.   For example, this can be done by making sure changes to JSON objects are done by either only adding new JSON elements to existing JSON objects, or when adding a new JSON object while still supporting the old one.  

Some very good guidance on designing resilient APIs is at https://mathieu.fenniak.net/stop-designing-fragile-web-apis/ and https://mathieu.fenniak.net/the-api-checklist/

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer:  Asset APIs use RESTful design patterns and uses versioning in the URI - OR - standard parseable document technologies for data transfer (SOAP, XML, JSON, GeoJSON, KML, etc. over HTTP) and documents contains versioning information AND service endpoints for the different versions of the API are maintained across versions.

Example good answer: Asset APIs use standard parseable document technologies for data transfer (SOAP, XML, JSON, GeoJSON, KML, etc. over HTTP) - OR - service interface uses RESTful design patterns BUT no versioning in the API or the XML documents.

Example bad answer: Asset APIs use proprietary, platform-dependent interfaces (e.g. RPC, JDBC) AND/OR API methods and arguments contain implemetation-specific information (e.g. arguments matching the underlying database column headers).

This question applies to all assets that have user interfaces, and is getting at whether and how consistently user input is validated during or after entry and what visual feedback is provided back to the user.User input validation may include but not limited to the following:

  • Boundary and range checking, such as min / max for numeric, min / max length for strings, choice from a list of allowed values
  • Check for input of required fields
  • Data type specific checks for validity (e.g. email addresses, phone numbers, URLs, coordinates)
  • Security checks (e.g. illegal characters, injected scripts)

To that end, client-side input validation (e.g. using JavaScript) is desired, so immediate feed-back can be provided to user before focus leaves field. Note that, when using client-side input validations, it is still important to have server-side validation, to prevent ill-intentioned clients from bypassing the client-side UI and access the server-side API directly.

All form data values/Server request parameters should be checked for valid syntax for target data type, e.g., integer, email, decimal (aka floating pt), URL, UTF-8 encoding.

question.narrative:
This question is getting at whether the output has been properly validated before sending to the original requester or forwarding to another service, etc.  Output validating is particularly important for enterprise services or for redeployable applications that provide a web service.  One thing to look for from a design perspective is whether the output can be exploited by a smart developer (e.g., if it uses consecutive numbers as customer identifiers, any one customer can fairly easily take advantage of that fact and find out data about other customers).  The best way to validate this is by inspection - of both the API and its implementation, and/or via looking at whether the SDLC process has explicitly called out output validation as a concern and provided developers a list of things to check (e.g., see #4 below) 

Output validation also includes ensuring that all output data is not only functionally and syntactically correct, but that they also conform to the published API specification. An asset may, for instance, return a valid XML document as output, but the document may not necessarily conform to the published XML schema (XSD or DTD). In the ideal case, the output data is automatically checked against the schema for conformance, before the response is sent (certain XML appliances provide this functionality separate from the software code).

1) From the OWASP site (https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Output_Validation):

Output validation refers to the process of validating the output of a process before it is sent to some recepient. For example, if you search your output for credit card numbers and replace them with asterisks (*), you have validated the output before sending it. You might also validate the output for common attacks, such as Cross-site Scripting (XSS) and SQL Injection before sending it.

NOTE: See HTML Entity Encoding which is a sort of output validation.

2) From the Security Ninja site (http://www.securityninja.co.uk/secure-development/output-validation/)

In addition to validating all of the data your application receives you should also follow similar processes for the data your application will output. Some attacks such as Cross Site Scripting can take advantage of poorly validated output to attack unsuspecting end users through your application. There are three main issues associated with output validation that you should always aim to address in your application; they are data encoding, data format and data length.

The data encoding process is slightly different depending on where your output is going to end up. For example if your data is going into a URL you need to ensure it is URL encoded. Output handling

Output handling is how an application, server or system handles the output (e.g. generating HTML, printing, logging, ...). It is important to keep in mind output often contains input supplied from users, clients, network, databases etc.

Secure output handling is primarily associated with preventing Cross-site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities, but could also prove to be important in similar areas (e.g. if generating Microsoft Office documents with some API, output management could potentially be required to prevent macro-injections).

Encode (escape) output

"Encoding" processes content that is about to be output so that any potentially dangerous characters are made safe. Characters from a typical known safe charset for the particular destination medium are often left as they are. A simple encoding might leave alone alphanumerics a-z, A-Z and 0-9. Any other characters could be possibly interpreted in an unexpected manner, and are therefore replaced with the appropriate "encoded" representation.

Question: Is the asset tested at the asset level? 

 

Narrative: This question is getting at whether the asset owner dedicates time and effort testing the asset itself as opposed to only testing the system that the asset is part of.   This is important to asses because a particular "end-2-end" test that applies to one system will likely not apply to a different system that wants to re-use the particular asset.  In order for an asset to be "enterprise grade", the asset owner needs to emphasize testing the asset itself.  By emphasizing the asset-level testing, the asset owner (and subsequent re-users) can be assured that the asset can be re-used in different end-2-end scenarios than those that the asset owner first considered. 

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.  Evidence that such testing has occured will be based on interviews with the asset owner, and the availability of testing artifacts that show asset-level testing (e.g., test plans and results, etc.)

  • Test cases, including scenarios and detailed procedures

This question applies to enterprise services or redeployable capabilities that include a user interface, and is getting at whether testing and evaluation activities have specifically included usability testing as a conscious effort.  This is important to ensure end user buy-in.  Usability is an important quality attribute and often determines the ultimate acceptance and "popularity" across the larger community. Testing and evaluation activities, therefore, should include usability as an integral part of the testing activities, along with functional testing, performance testing, etc. Here this question's scoring criteria describe three levels of maturity in usability testing:

  • In the best case scenario, the asset's UIs have been through formal usability testing based on well-defined metrics and test cases (e.g. personas, scenarios, etc.). One of the most important metrics is end user feedback on the ease-of-use and friendliness of the asset. If events such as an Operational Utility Evaluation (OUE) has been conducted and user feedback gets incorporated into the system development, the asset is likely to have strong buy-in from the user community.
  • In a less ideal scenario, the asset's UIs have been through informal usability expert evaluation or heuristics-based review based on well-defined metrics (e.g. Nielsen's Heuristics) and test cases, but no formal usability testing is conducted. In this case, the team has make a conscious effort to review the asset's usability from the user's perspective, but no usability testing involving end user feedback is conducted.
  • In the the worse case, usability test cases and metrics are not defined; no explicit usability testing has been conducted. This lack of a conscious effort by the asset development team is often the result of a "we know best what users want" mentality and may hinder the asset's acceptance and incur serious technical debt in the future.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

question.narrative:
Narrative: This question looks to see whether an asset provides mechanisms for collecting its runtime metrics. In a component-based, service-oriented architecture, an asset cannot expect to have its own dedicated monitoring and maintenance operations; rather, the asset should in general lend itself to be monitored and maintained as part of a larger system deployment. To this end, it is desirable to have API-level integration "hooks" for up-to-date asset usage data such as:

  • Status and health (e.g. a sub-component failure, a communication timeout, etc.)
  • Utilization / load (e.g. response time, thoughput)
  • Abnormal usage as it occurs (e.g. violation of SLAs)
  • Transactional data for auditing purposes (e.g. user ID and timestamp for major events)

Such APIs may be "push" and/or "pull", although the former is more common in a "monitoring agent â€“ monitoring sever" architecture, where each asset contains a monitoring agent that feeds usage data to a dedicated monitoring server. Such architectures have been widely used in the system management and network management domains (e.g. the CMIP and SNMP protocols) as well as modern software frameworks (e.g. JMX). SOA systems, in particular, leverage service management and monitoring specifications such as Web Services Distributed Management (WSDM) and WS-Notification to enable loose-coupling between service components being monitored and the monitoring functions themselves.

For finer-grained assets (e.g. a UI widget), monitoring may be achieved through integration "hooks" already provided in the container framework (e.g. OWF, JEE).

To score high in this question, the asset should not only provide sufficient runtime mechanisms for the collection of aforementioned metrics, but should ideally leverage standard-based protocols and/or platform-independent frameworks for the exchange of such metrics, in order to avoid locking in to a proprietary monitoring/auditing architecture or product.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: The asset provides sufficient standard-based and/or framework-provided integration points for collecting runtime metrics in a platform- and product-independent fashion.

Example good answer: The asset provides sufficient APIs or leverages framework-provided integration points for collecting runtime metrics but requires platform- or product-specific integration

Example bad answer: The asset does not provide sufficient mechanisms for runtime monitoring.

question.narrative:
Question: Does UI experience any notable response delay to specific operations?

 

Narrative: The question is concerned with the responsiveness of UI. A responsive user interface should immediately reacts to user input with no discernible delay  (e.g., a map widget becomes unresponsive while loading its KML layers). As a rule of thumb, it should usually take less than 3 seconds to respond to user action and provides visual feedback to the user when the operation is expected to take longer than 1-2 seconds. The scoring criterion identifies three levels of responsiveness:

 This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: UI immediately reflects user input with no discernible delay and usually takes less than 3 seconds to respond to user action and provides feedback to the user when the delay is longer than 2 seconds (e.g., hour glass icon is display for map loading).

Example good answer: UI immediately reflects user input with no discernible delay and usually takes less than 6 seconds to respond to user action, and provides feedback to the user that it is in process when delay is longer than 4 seconds.

Example bad answer: UI takes considerable time (e.g., more than 1 second) to reflect user action (e.g., showing button click lags the click itself, characters show up more than 1 second after typing, etc.) and/or more than 8 seconds to respond to user action (e.g., from submit to data response) and there is no feedback to the user that it is in process.

 

Question: Does the UI load/initialize in a reasonable time?

 

Narrative: This question focused on the initial loading time of the UI (whether thin or thick client, or widget). Frequently, a user interface needs to instantiate itself on the client machine (think client) or in the client browser (thin client or web widget) followed by necessary initialization (e.g. loading reference data sets, loading the initial map). Pre-loading lots of data may help expedite subsequent operations, yet may come at the expense of a long waiting period upfront. A good design practice is "lazy initialization", i.e. load data items only when they are used for the first time, which reduces the initial loading time and a better user experience.  Additionally, the UI "footprint" should be minimized (e.g., by "minifying" javascript code).

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

The scoring criterion is based on how long the UI initializes itself:

 Example best answer: UI take less than 3 seconds to load/initialize

 Example good answer:  UI takes between 3-8 seconds to load/initialize

 Example bad answer: UI takes more than 8 seconds to load/initialize

 

Not applicable if asset does not include a UI

 

Question: Does the asset perform its functions in reasonable and expected response times?

 

Narrative: This questions are intended for "back-end" components such as an enterprise service (accessible over the network) or a redeployed capability (a local instantiation within the system/program of record). The "reasonable" response times will vary from asset to asset.  For example, for a Security Token Service provided by an enterprise or an enclave, a 1/2 second response time would be considered unacceptably long, whereas a one-second response for a Web Map Service may be considered fast. Nonetheless, there are reference points that may be used to judge the asset's performance. The scoring criterion of this question use the following as the basis of judging the responsiveness of the service component:

  • When available, use the performance requirements to which an asset has been designed and implemented. For components implemented for a program of record, for instance, there may be Key Performance Parameters (KPP), Key System Attributes (KSA), and other requirements that apply.
  • When defined, use the Quality of Service (QoS) and/or Service Level Agreements (SLAs) that apply for the asset.
  • Where applicable, established performance benchmarking software may be used for evaluation.
  • If available, a well-known component that provides equivalent functionality may be used as a benchmark to evaluate the asset of interest. 

When none of the above is available, subject expert opinion may be sought during evaluation.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: The asset exceeds applicable performance requirements and/or agreed-upon QoS/SLA levels, excels in applicable benchmarking tests, or performs better than well-known products providing equivalent functionality. (e.g., the ephemeris service produces tracks in XX milliseconds, exceeding the designed requirements).

Example good answer: The asset meets applicable performance requirements and/or agreed-upon QoS/SLA levels, passes applicable benchmarking tests, or performs comparably with well-known products providing equivalent functionality. (e.g., the messaging service performs comparatively with the IBM MQSeries in similar use cases).

Example bad answer: The asset fails to meet applicable performance requirements and/or agreed-upon QoS/SLA levels, fares poorly in applicable benchmarking tests, cannot match well-known products providing equivalent functionality, OR is otherwise considered falling short of the expected response times by a wide margin.  (e.g., the federated search service returns the consolidated results in 60 seconds or longer for certain searches, far longer than the SLA-specified 10-second response time).

question.narrative:
Question: Is the asset designed to maintain its performance levels under varying amounts of user requests and/or data?

 

Narrative: In many cases, an asset (either an enterprise service or a redeployed capability)'s performance is directly impacted by the level of demand, in terms of the number of concurrent user requests and/or the volume of data. A well-designed service should be capable of maintaining performance levels even under heavy load. This may be achieved through adequate resource allocation (e.g. server clusters), load monitoring and balancing, and (in cloud environments) elastic resource provisioning. Even under limited resource allocations, the asset should ideally be cognizant of its performance limitations and manage consumers expectations (e.g. stop receiving further requests until the situation improves and provide a meaningful message - analogous to putting a customer service phone call on hold and advise the estimated wait time).

See http://www.perftestplus.com/resources/how_fast.pdf, http://www.webperformancematters.com/journal/2007/7/10/acceptable-response-times.html, and http://www.nngroup.com/articles/response-times-3-important-limits/ for information on response times

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: The asset's configuration allows auto-scaling with use and, when so configured, there is no discernible difference with increasing connections and increased data accessed per connection (e.g., the asset employs a software load-balancer component and virtualized processing and data-layer components that can be dynamically provisioned, allowing linear scalability).

Example good answer: The asset's configuration allows throttling of service requests and, when so configured, response times are consistent, but throttling limits the number of connections / users supported - OR - the asset's configuration allows scaling on one dimension (e.g., number of users) but not on other dimensions, such as the amount of data requested (e.g., the asset receives requests from a message queue with a fixed size, and surge requests will wait until the queue is not full - OR - the asset deploys in a JBoss server under a clustering configuration, but all JBoss instances point to a single database, limiting its scalability).

Example bad answer: The asset's configuration does not allow auto-scaling or throttling of service requests, and service response times vary widely due to usage (e.g., the asset has no request management functionality and has a singleton component that becomes a bottleneck for scalability).

 

Question: Are the asset's resource requirements well understood?

 

Narrative: In order to operate a system the physical resource requirements should be well known. For a well designed scalable component (Question #610 focuses on this) it is very useful to understand the resource requirements based upon workload. For example, if it is known that a component running on a VM with 4 cores and 16G of memory can process 200 simultaneous user requests then it is reasonable to appropriately design a system based upon expected workloads. This information can be determined via load/performance testing, which should be well documented and described. 

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: The asset has well documented resource requirements based upon expected workloads and the resource requirements are expressed in terms of commodity hardware resources. Load testing test plans and test results are included with the documentation.

Example good answer: The asset has general performance information based upon workload in its documentation but it is not specific and not verified by test results. The resource requirements are based upon experience with an operational instance.

Example bad answer: No information is available on resource requirements based upon workload OR the resource needs are tied to specific proprietary hardware / systems

question.narrative:
This question is looking for whether the asset owner employs code security analysis tools as a regular part of the development phase of their software development lifecycle (SDLC). There is no way to guarantee the absence of vulnerabilities, but there are well-known ways to minimize the risk, or likelihood, of such vulnerabilities. These include leveraging a continuous integration (CI) development process that employs the automated running of both static code analysis tools (e.g., HP Fortify) and dynamic code analysis tools (e.g., Metasploit).  Note that many of the static code analysis tools generate false positives, so that just because a tool report shows, for example, a CAT 1 finding, it is important to follow that up with a manual review to validate that the CAT 1 finding is, in fact, NOT a false positive. This is why leveraging these tools during the SDLC is most effective - because feedback to the development team is regular and (almost) immediate - lowering the overall effort and cost to evaluate and address them.  If the analysis tools are only employed at the end of development, the cost to address any findings is much higher - which will generally result in only the most critical findings being addressed.  

It is also worth noting that static code analysis tools can only catch certain kinds of vulnerabilities (see write up on OWASP on SCA tools), and that dynamic code analysis tools are also required to get a more complete coverage of the asset.

This question is concerned with the application level security of the asset, i.e. the authentication, authorization, policy enforcement, auditing, etc. that is separate from the Mandatory Access Control (MAC) enforced by the residing network environment. question.narrative:
Question: Are there mechanisms to capture and track consumer feedback?

 

Narrative: Once an asset is offered to the larger community, the asset provider should provide mechanisms to formally and regularly seek consumer feedback. This is especially important for shared services or common components that have a large consumer base. By soliciting consumer feedback, defects can be identified and mitigated early before impacting the community at large, and future requirements can be accurately prioritized to make sure engineering efforts get better "bang for the buck". These mechanisms might include the following:

  • Change request and bug tracking processes
  • Online portals
  • Discussion forums
  • Social media
  • Technical exchange meetings (TEM), held regularly with user representatives
  • Helpdesk and technical support channels

Having open channels to receive consumer feedback is just the starting point. Consumer requests should be acknowledged in a timely manner and tracked to completion, with appropriate actions taken (e.g. CR submitted to address a defect, new requirement entered into feature backlog, etc.)

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: Formal mechanism provided for consumer feedback.  Multiple online venues exist to solicit feedback.  Feedback formally tracked to completion (or rejection).Consumer Feedback actively solicited (e.g., PoR holds periodic TEMs with the user community, etc.)

Example good answer: Reactive response, but no active solicitation of consumer feedback (e.g. help desk and technical support POCs are offered and responsive to customer requests)

Example bad answer: No mechanism in place to capture consumer feedback; or support POCs exist, but are not responsive.

 

Question: Is there an active community of users and/or developers?

 

Narrative: An asset should foster an open, active community for the consumers (end users, developers, or other interested party) to freely collaborate and share information. The community serves a dual purpose: it not only helps the asset owner "feel the pulse" of its user base and gain awareness on how the asset is being used, but also gives the user community a venue to network among themselves and help one another. The community can provide a wealth of information that the asset provider can "mine" to continually improve the asset's functionality and quality. As a simple example, by tracking user growth in various organizations / mission areas and the "tag cloud" of hot topics in user discussion forums, the the asset provider can identify trends and patterns that better informs the future budget process and proactively allocate resources.

There can be multiple venues for community outreach as mentioned in Question #800, but the most effective way is to have an openly accessible online presence (e.g. a wiki site), augmented by social media when possible. The effectiveness of the venues can be best judged by the active participation of the users and developers.

For open source assets, it is even more critical that an active community of developers exists in order to ensure that the asset will continue to mature.  Note that question #860  gets at the additional venues such as GitHub or the DI2E Developer Tools that are necessary to collaborate on code development, this question is looking at whether such an active community exists.  If there is no active community of either users or developers, that would imply that the asset is in danger of getting "stale", and increases the risk of another program re-using this asset if they don't also provide developers to maintain it.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS - although for COTS and GOTS where source code is not available this might be limited to an active community providing feedback and helping other implementers of the asset.

Example best answer: Yes, many users and developers are actively participating in the asset lifecycle as can be seen by looking at online developer Wiki and seeing daily / weekly posts from various participants.

Example good answer: Yes, some users and/or developers are participating in the asset lifecycle, but they are not very active as can be seen by, for example, an Intelink community page used for collaboration with few participants and infrequent (quarterly or less) updates

Example bad answer: No. The asset provider does not track the users and/or developers using this asset or promote their collaboration, or if they do there is no evidence of any developers/users participating.

 

Question: Does the community provide independent information on the usage of the asset?

 

Narrative: The intent of this question is to ascertain whether there is a free flow of information about this asset between users and other stakeholders of the asset or whether all information about the asset is only from the asset owner. As mentioned in Question #910, an asset should foster an open, active community of developers and users (i.e., the consumers, end users, developers, or other interested parties).  This question gets at whether that community can freely collaborate and share information. This community serves a dual purpose: it not only helps the asset owner "feel the pulse" of its user base and gain awareness on how the asset is being used, but also gives the user community a venue to network among themselves and help one another. Information and experience sharing among consumers often leads to more efficient support and even better insights on the asset than one-way information from the asset provider alone. For example, a new user may need to wait for a day or two to get a response to a simple question from the official technical support POC, but posting the question to the community may generate multiple answers in a matter of minutes.

It may be uncomfortable and sometimes takes a mindset change on the asset provider's part to allow for independent, "unofficial" information on the usage of the asset, among the user community. However, the benefits of having a thriving, collaborating community that supports one another will by far outweigh any concerns of "losing control".

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: Yes, and there is an open, free flow of a breadth of information amongs all stakeholders through multiple channels, and stakeholders can find useful information about the asset in addition to that is offered by the asset provider.  E.g., online developer Wiki is openly accessible; consumers can find useful information about the asset in addition to what is offered by the asset provider.

Example good answer: Yes, there is some flow of information through limited channel(s) such as a user forum, a mailing list, or document sharing, etc.  Some useful information can be found beyond what the asset provider has already provided. E.g., Intelink community page exists that requires CAC access;

Example bad answer: No, there is no independent information offered by the stakeholders beyond what is already offered by the asset provider.  No collaborative venue exists for the stakeholders.

question.narrative:
To support the enhancement and evolution of its implementations, an asset should define and execute a versioning strategy that involves consistent and meaningful versioning schemes, versioning documentation, mechanisms for version discovery, and careful considerations for backward-compatibility. Such a strategy gives consumers the ability to adapt to a new version or provide meaningful feedback describing the incompatibility or difference. In the best case scenario, the asset's versioning strategy should achieve the following:

  • The versioning scheme is consistent, easy to understand, and predictable
  • The versioning scheme indicates backward compatibility, e.g. using major and minor version numbers
  • Version information is clearly displayed in user interfaces, e.g. in an application title bar, through an about box, etc.
  • Asset documentation clearly reflects versioning and version-specific data (e.g. via a VDD document).
  • Version information is included in discovery metadata about the asset.

In the worst case, an asset has no meaningful versioning strategy to speak of, and version information is either lacking, inconsistent, or not discoverable.

There are additional considerations for the versioning strategy to cover as well:

  • Any changes should minimize impacts to the consumer
  • When non-backwards compatible changes have to be made, they should be obvious and easily discoverable 
  • When a new non-backwards compatible version is created, support for the older version should be maintained for a reasonable period of time and old versions should still be available while supported
  • A version roadmap should exist that describes how long versions will be supported and when versions are expected to be deprecated

Clients are able to adapt to the new version or provide meaningful feedback describing the incompatibility or difference; major and minor versions are easily recognizable through the versioning scheme; software version is displayed in an application title bar, through an about box, or similarly familiar user expectation; for a widget the version is recognizable through the download link/folder name, and/or documentation is clearly marked; for an Enterprise Service asset (e.g., web service) has to come from its service documentation such as an Interface Description Document (WSDL, WADL) or version is specified in the URL.

See http://semver.org/ or http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff384251.aspx for more info on versioning strategies

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: The asset follows a versioning strategy that is well-defined and predictable (e.g. there is a versioning scheme included in file format, network protocols, etc.; major and minor versions are easily recognizable through the versioning scheme; current version of the running software can be easily determined via the "about" dialog, and so on.). 

Example good answer: A coherent and predictable versioning strategy is not defined, but the asset's history shows adherence to some of the versioning tenets and best practices.  

Example bad answer: No versioning scheme is defined, or there exists evidence that shows the asset does not follow (or explicitly violates) versioning tenets and best practices.
question.objective:
For this question, we are looking for a versioning strategy that is well-defined and predictable, and a clear definition of the versioning scheme.

An example of a versioning strategy is the following:

Deploy a new version every 3 months, ensure backwards compatibility with previous two versions, and if a non-backwards compatible API update needs to be made, the old API will be kept for at least one year.

An example numbering scheme is the following:

  1. major.minor.patch
    1. major = non-backwards compatible change
    2. minor = backwards compatible enhancement
    3. patch = backwards compatible bug fix

 

See http://semver.org/ or http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff384251.aspx or https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_versioning for more info on versioning strategies and schemes

The highest scoring assets would have detailed dependencies and descriptions of the licenses in use, and have been scanned by a tool similar to the COTS tools that determine open source and license usage. The report from the tool could be included to provide additional useful documentation on the licensing.  

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

Example best answer: Yes, license is well documented and easy to understand and/or leverages an already defined well-known license (e.g., from http://opensource.org/licenses/category).  Includes report from license scanning tool.

Example good answer: License is documented and consistently applied across all code, but the license itself has areas that are not clear and needs interpretation.

Example bad answer: License is not documented or well defined; rights and licenses are inconsistently placed in code (or absent), license is very confusing and appears internally inconsistent.

question.narrative:
Development planning cycles are typically fairly long, and for a complex ecosystem of components and consumers planning can become particularly difficult. In order to make this easier and to provide additional confidence to consumers the POR should have a roadmap for the asset covering approximately the next three releases. 

If we look to the software industry as an example we see that roadmaps are a required part of a product's information - without it consumers have difficulty understanding how the software will be evolving and it hampers sales (sales are analogous to reuse in our environment). There is typically also some expectation that the roadmap will adjust based upon user feedback.

The product roadmap may not be (typically won't be) included in the software and documentation and will likely have to be obtained directly from the POR. If it is included in the documentation that is an indicator that the POR is forward thinking and understands the value of communicating longer term plans. To evaluate review the plan and look for plans that provide good details in the short term (one release) and become more vague in the later releases. Plans that provide high levels of details 5 releases out are likely mostly fictional and can actually do more harm than good. Also see how difficult it is for the POR to produce a plan - is it something they have on hand or did they create it just for your request? A mechanism for capturing high level and long term user needs is also a positive sign.

This question applies equally to COTS, GOTS, FOSS and GOSS.

 

Example best answer: Yes, and it includes a timeline going out at least three major releases.  Also, there is a mechanism for user/developer/admin input.

Example good answer: Yes, but it only provides the expected order of evolution of capabilities (i.e. no timeline).

Example bad answer: No roadmap provided

question.narrative:
The intent of this question is to make sure that the asset owner has expressed a willingness to support the asset as a "re-usable enterprise asset" as opposed to only supporting it for their own internal needs (or dropping support for it altogether).  In order for an asset to be reused, the reusers must have confidence that the asset will not languish unchanged forever and that there is some mechanism to get bugs fixed and issues addressed (potentially including things like help with debugging problems). Support for the asset can be accomplished in a number of ways, a minimum of which includes:

  • The owning POR maintains and manages the asset as an enterprise asset. Ideally they build and maintain the asset truly as a separate component and then integrate it back into their own system just like other consumers would do (see Eating your own dog food). The owning POR has mechanisms to accept bugs/issues/enhancement requests from external customers (note that may be facilitated via the DI2E Framework).
  • The code is made available (in buildable condition - not just a source dump) at a government location such as the DI2E Framework developer environment. This is analogous to code escrow often required for small COTS vendors when large commercial organizations purchase their products - the code escrow reduces the risk to the organization if the small vendor goes out of business. This is not the optimal solution but does ensure that the consumer of the asset can pick up maintenance if necessary (i.e., the original owning POR stops supporting the asset or goes away). 

  • The POR has the desire to and/or sets up the processes to support being an enterprise service/capability provider. Programs that are unwilling generally totally ignore or otherwise spend no time or money at all in setting up processes/mechanisms to help with re-use (e.g., they hide their code and executables behind firewalls that nobody can access, etc.). 

     

Additionally the following will also help with long term support of an asset:

  • The asset can be made available as open source (FOSS or GOSS). Then each POR who uses the asset can make their own fixes and changes as necessary - hopefully coordinating with the broader community to prevent forking. 
  • Establishment of overall mechanisms to allow for a community to communicate about the asset - e.g., plans and issues, roadmaps, etc.
  • Long term funding for the asset exists. Even if the POR is willing to support the asset they may not have the funding profile to fulfill their desires. Most programs don't share funding information so this is a more difficult aspect to assess. Again note that the DI2E Framework or other organizations with an enterprise focus (such as USD(I) itself) may be providing funding to support enterprise assets as well. 

There are various shades to this - most often the typical case will be that the POR will continue to build and enhance the asset as part of the continued maintenance of their system, but they aren't really treating it as an enterprise asset.

Example best answer: Yes. The POR has explicitly stated that they will support the asset as an enterprise asset and has applied funding to do so.

Example good answer: The POR has stated they will support others' use of the asset on a limited basis, but due to funding or other constraints are not willing to support the asset as a full enterprise asset. 

Example bad answer: No, the POR is not willing to support the asset as an enterprise asset.

section.content:
Installation instructions for the Apex framework were not clearly organized into any unified installation guide. As Apex is closely tied to Hadoop, it appears necessary for users to go through the Hadoop installation process. Beyond that, information on installing Apex by itself was not found. However, it is possible to set up a machine with a mock Hadoop instance in order to test Apex itself. DataTorrent provides a virtual machine image with the necessary Hadoop dependencies already provided, and this was used for testing. In addition to Hadoop, Apex also requires Maven and the Java software development kit (SDK).

 For the purposes of evaluation a Virtual Machine appliance was downloaded and used from the internet. Link is here. This file created a VM image that would start with Hadoop services already up and running, as well as a current installation of apex, maven, and the Java SDK.

 

The file that is downloaded is a virtual box appliance file, this file will build the VM preseeded with values. 

To build the VM in virutal box:

1. Go to: File >> Import Appliance >> (location of .ova file) >> Next >> (Accept the defaults) >> Import.

2. After the imort step the VM can be started as normal.
